Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Remote and Directive Electromagnetic Stimulation of Transport Mechanisms to Enhance Soil Remediation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Farid
0928703

EM fields can oscillate water dipole molecules, which can in turn stimulate mechanisms such as airflow, seepage, microbial activities, desorption, and volatilization. Several soil remediation technologies inject air into soil to enhance microbial activities for bioremediation and volatilization of organic contaminants for soil cleanup. The goal of this study is to electromagnetic ally stimulate mechanisms to enhance soil remediation. Recent research has also shown a strong potential to mitigate liquefaction by air sparging. Increasing air injection pressure will create air channels within high porosity zones for easy airflow. These channels are preferential paths for flow of the majority of the injected air. The size, spacing, and formation of these air channels cannot be controlled and air diffusion between these channels is extremely slow. Electric current has become popular to enhance remediation processes. However, electric current will find preferential paths of relatively higher electrical conductivity. In sandy or even highly conductive lossy clayey soils, relatively higher conductivity zones are the same high porosity zones, previously taken by air channels. EM waves can oscillate water dipole molecules to stimulate and enhance different transport mechanisms and increase hydraulic conductivity. EM waves propagate better in zones of low conductivity (low porosity zones (untouched by the previously mentioned methods). EM waves antennas can be designed to operate above ground, be directive to input more power in desired direction, and focus energy into desired locations with constructive radiation patterns. The heating effect due to oscillation by an EM field can also be controlled more easily than electric fields, using low voltage high frequency waves. Effect of variations in frequency and power level on enhancement of different transport mechanisms and microbial activities need to be studied. This study is essential for developing theoretical models necessary to simulate these interactions. In addition to enhancing airflow, the stimulation has the potential to enhance volatilization, microbial activities, and desorption of chemicals and heavy metals from soil-grains for cleanup. The project will also integrate research, education, and active collaboration with industry. One multidisciplinary graduate student will participate as will undergraduate and high school students and teachers. The PIs will continue to expand their connection with Boise high schools through the TRiO (Upward Bound Summer Internship) program at Boise State University (BSU) with summer internships. A website will be developed to deliver the research outcome to practitioners and academic communities, especially the large group of companies within the initiated collaborative group. With the help from the BSU TRiO program, portions of the website will be designed for high school and middle school students and linked to Boise public school websites.

Overview: Groundwater is the primary source of drinking water for more than 50% of the U.S. population. This has made groundwater a critical asset for America today. However, every year, more than 1.6 trillion Gallons of contaminants, directly buried within ground, and more than 10,000 aging underground storage tanks, leaking into ground, contaminate groundwater across the nation.

Mother earth naturally cleans contaminants through natural volatilization and biodegradation. Volatilization is a process in which volatile contaminants vaporize and move into the atmosphere to disperse. Biodegradation is another process in which soils’ indigenous microbes digest contaminants into less-toxic waste. However, these two natural processes are extremely slow, which creates an urgent need to develop technologies to clean up contaminated groundwater and soil. There are two categories of technologies for groundwater and soil cleanup, ex situ and in situ.

Ex-situ methods require excavation and extraction of contaminated soil or groundwater to be shipped off-site for cleanup. One example is the dig-and-treat method. For obvious reasons, ex-situ cleanup is very costly and destructive.

In-situ techniques are less destructive and cost-effective methods of enhancing natural volatilization and biodegradation on site and without extraction.

Air sparging is one of the most innovative in-situ methods. Air sparging is very popular due to its two-fold nature. In this method, air or oxygen is injected into soil to help vaporize volatile contaminants. Oxygen also feeds aerobic biodegradation –by microbes that need oxygen to survive.

Air sparing is ineffective since it is limited by uncontrolled airflow within soil. In air sparging, wells are drilled into ground to pump air into groundwater. Similar to when one blows air through a straw into a cup of water, air injected into groundwater turns into bubbles or channels and flows to surface. When air channels are formed, further injected air will flow through those channels to surface and not spread into groundwater. The size and spacing of air channels cannot be controlled. The airflow between air channels is also extremely slow. There is a need for enhancement of air delivery in air sparging.

Scientists have used tools such as electricity to direct airflow towards contaminants or contaminant flow toward the injected air. The electricity can be used in the form of DC (direct current, similar to that of batteries) or AC (alternating current similar to the one used in every house). The use of electricity requires digging trenches to install expensive electrodes. The electric current corrodes electrodes, heats up the soil and groundwater up to 100oC, and can even alter the pH (i.e., acidity) of soil, killing microbes responsible for biodegradation for which the oxygen and air are injected.

Scientific Merit: Through this NSF-funded project, we have developed an alternative that leverages electromagnetic (EM) waves to remotely clean up contaminants. Among the benefits of this method are that EM waves do not alter pH and, as shown by our team, the generated heat by EM waves can be minimized at proper frequencies. Another great benefit of this technology that makes it very cost-effective and nondestructive is that EM waves can be launched using above-ground antennas, eliminating the need for excavation and installation of electrodes. EM radiation patterns can also be tailored to contain or move contaminants to extraction wells, enhance airflow for air sparging, enhance oxygen supply to aerobic microbes responsible for bioremediation, and many more. EM antennas can even be designed to focus the energy at specific points and leave other points untouched, similar to methods used to treat cancer.
